title: The Dow’s Gains Suddenly Disappeared After Reports the U.S. Is Considering Delisting Chinese Stocks
text:
Text size

12:06 p.m. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gave back all its gains after reports emerged that the U.S. was considering banning portfolio flows into China.

The Dow has advanced 5.54 points to 26,896.665.54, while the S&P 500 has dipped 0.2% to 2971.88, and the Nasdaq Composite has fallen 0.4% to 7995.19.

The U.S. is considering delisting all Chinese companies, according to Bloomberg, and banning U.S. pensions from investing in Chinese stocks. Details remain scant, and the plan would still need to be approved by President Donald Trump. The Dow had been up well over 100 points when the news broke.

“This story pretty came out of nowhere and the timing is terrible,” writes Oanda’s Edward Moya. “US equities sold off strongly and safe-havens soared as much of Europe has already started their weekends.”

The report must come for a shock to investors hoping that the U.S. and China were close to reaching a trade truce. It has also caused Chinese stocks to fall, as the iShares China Large-Cap ETF (FXI) has slipped 1.1% to $39.47. Alibaba (BABA) has dropped 4.5% to $167.05.

More to come.

Markets Now is a quick take on what’s happening with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and other major market indexes. Don’t forget to check out the rest of Barron’s markets coverage.

Write to Ben Levisohn at Ben.Levisohn@barrons.com
description: The U.S. is considering delisting all Chinese companies, according to Bloomberg, and banning U.S. pensions from investing in Chinese stocks. Details remain scant, and the plan would still need to be approved by President Donald Trump.
